subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: [RTSC] RT-EVP
author: Tim Woolworth
full_text:
Jerome,

I love this:

"I feel it's at least a *3 PART* dynamic and one which exists between the
device itself, the operator and those on the other side."

Very succinct and from my experience I find it to be quite true.  For me,
the most uncontrollable aspect of this dynamic is the device itself.  I use
Minibox Pluses and a Joe's Box because they work for me.  But, if you put a
Shack Hack in my hands, it works but not nearly as well.  Others experience
amazing results with Shack hacks.  I was experimenting with a Shack Hack
about a month back and the communication wasn't clear enough but I got the
gist of what they were saying.  I asked them to hold on while I switched
boxes and the conversation continued with the same guy from the other side.
 The conversations and communicators are there, always.  This is why I put a
premium on the equipment being used because I know that I already have a
connection with the other side that can be facilitated on any box designed
to do so, but only a few boxes have worked to my personal satisfaction so
far.

Tim

On Mon, Oct 25, 2010 at 3:04 PM, Mvanah Maloti <inyanga4@yahoo.com> wrote:

>
>
> *CB* brings up a great point in that each user has their own input and
> individual "key" regarding how well a certain device is going to work for
> them. I think the same holds true for the impetus, energy and intelligence
> behind the GB phenomenon...certainly "they" have just as much to do with it
> as "we" do...(perhaps even more so!).
>
> I feel it's at least a *3 PART* dynamic and one which exists between the
> device itself, the operator and those on the other side.
>
> I'm in agreement that what works best for one might be horrible for another
> (& vice versa) and this is something we could all do well to keep in mind -
> perhaps especially myself as I've been quite harsh with a few devices in the
> past and my own opinion and experience with them is the furthest thing from
> the "holy work" or final word on the subject. Like everyone else here I
> experiment, conduct my sessions, record my work and file my research in
> effort to find what works best FOR ME and garners the greatest results.
>
> Part of what makes this field, our individual work and collective efforts
> so exciting and progressive is that each researcher brings their own
> unique approach and combined experience to the table. I don't think ITC
> research would ever grow or progress if everyone used the same devices or
> recorded their sessions in the same way, naturally.
>
> That said, if you're still interested in testing and experimenting
> with this device to see if you like it or not, Michael, I'd be happy to send
> you mine to experiment with if you're open to paying for postage and return
> shipping. I'd rather see the devices in my care and the equipment I've
> invested in be actively used or sold or at least scrapped for parts to
> create other devices when and where possible. Practically any ITC device can
> get some kind of results and who knows? Perhaps the *RT-EVP* will work
> better for you than it has for me...you might even fall in love with it and
> be able to show me all the things I've missed!
>
> Best,
> Jerome
>
>
>
>  
>
